Docs.summary: Represents an individual data item in a control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem> class represents an individual data item in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control. A data item usually corresponds to a record in a data source object. The class derives from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewItem> class.
Each item in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control has a designated item type that is represented by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewItem.ItemType%2A> property. When the item type is <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewItemType?displayProperty=fullName>, you can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem> class to get more information about the item.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control stores data items in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView.Items%2A> collection. To determine the index of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem> object in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView.Items%2A> collection, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem.DisplayIndex%2A> property. To determine the index of the data item in the underlying data source, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem.DataItemIndex%2A> property. The difference between these index properties is that <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem.DisplayIndex%2A> represents the position of the data item in the current page, whereas <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem.DataItemIndex%2A> is based on the page offset. If the paging functionality is not enabled in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control by using a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DataPager> control, these two properties will contain the same value.
You can access the properties of the underlying data object by using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem.DataItem%2A> property.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem.DataItem%2A> property is available only during and after the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView.ItemDataBound> event of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control.
For a list of initial property values for an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem> class, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem.%23ctor%2A> constructor.
## Examples The following example shows how to use a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem> object to retrieve a field value from an item in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control.
> [!IMPORTANT] > This example has a text box that accepts user input, which is a potential security threat. By default, ASP.NET Web pages validate that user input does not include script or HTML elements. For more information, see [Script Exploits Overview](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/772c7312-211a-4eb3-8d6e-eec0aa1dcc07).

## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem.DisplayIndex%2A> property corresponds to the current position of the item as displayed by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView> control. Each item's <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem.DisplayIndex%2A> value reflects the order in which they were added to the control in that particular page of data. You can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem.DisplayIndex%2A> property to retrieve a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem> object in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListView.Items%2A> collection.
> [!NOTE] > This property applies only to data items. It does not apply to insert items or empty items.
## Examples The following example shows how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ListViewDataItem.DisplayIndex%2A> property to retrieve the index of the item that is being edited.
